PronType.title: pronominal type
PronType.description: This feature typically applies to pronouns, pronominal adjectives (determiners), pronominal numerals (quantifiers) and pronominal adverbs.

Gender.title: gender
Gender.description: Gender is usually a lexical feature of nouns and inflectional feature of other parts of speech (pronouns, adjectives, determiners, numerals, verbs) that mark agreement with nouns.

VerbForm.title: form of verb or deverbative
VerbForm.description: Some verb forms in some languages actually form a gray zone between verbs and other parts of speech (nouns, adjectives and adverbs).

NumType.title: numeral type
NumType.description: It includes almost everything where counting is involved and there are various subtypes and applies to seral part-of-speach tags(NUM, DET, ADJ, ADV).

Animacy.title: animacy
Animacy.description: Similarly to Gender (and to the African noun classes), animacy is usually a lexical feature of nouns and inflectional feature of other parts of speech (pronouns, adjectives, determiners, numerals, verbs) that mark agreement with nouns.

Mood.title: mood
Mood.description: Mood is a feature that expresses modality and subclassifies finite verb forms.

Poss.title: possessive
Poss.description: It tells whether the word is possessive.

NounClass.title: noun class
NounClass.description: NounClass is similar to Gender and Animacy because it is to a large part a lexical category of nouns and other parts of speech inflect for it to show agreement (pronouns, adjectives, determiners, numerals, verbs).

Tense.title: tense
Tense.description: Tense is typically a feature of verbs. It may also occur with other parts of speech (nouns, adjectives, adverbs), depending on whether borderline word forms such as participles are classified as verbs or as the other category.

Reflex.title: reflexive
Reflex.description: It tells whether the word is reflexive, i.e. refers to the subject of its clause.

Number.title: number
Number.description: Number is usually an inflectional feature of nouns and, depending on language, other parts of speech (pronouns, adjectives, determiners, numerals, verbs) that mark agreement with nouns.

Aspect.title: aspect
Aspect.description: Aspect is a feature that specifies duration of the action in time, whether the action has been completed etc.

Foreign.title: a foreign word
Foreign.description: Is this a foreign word? Not a loan word and not a foreign name but a genuinely foreign word appearing inside native text, e.g. inside direct speech, titles of books etc.

Case.title: case
Case.description: Case is usually an inflectional feature of nouns and, depending on language, other parts of speech (pronouns, adjectives, determiners, numerals, verbs) that mark agreement with nouns.

Voice.title: voice
Voice.description: Voice is typically a feature of verbs. It may also occur with other parts of speech (nouns, adjectives, adverbs), depending on whether borderline word forms such as gerunds and participles are classified as verbs or as the other category.

Abbr.title: abbreviation
Abbr.description: Is this an abbreviation? Note that the abbreviated word(s) typically belongs to a part of speech other than X.

Definite.title: definiteness or state
Definite.description: Definiteness is typically a feature of nouns, adjectives and articles. Its value distinguishes whether we are talking about something known and concrete, or something general or unknown.

Evident.title: evidentiality
Evident.description: Evidentiality is the morphological marking of a speaker’s source of information (Aikhenvald, 2004). It is sometimes viewed as a category of mood and modality.

Typo.title: is this a misspelled word?
Typo.description: Indicates bad spelling, grammatical error etc.

Degree.title: degree of comparison
Degree.description: Degree of comparison is typically an inflectional feature of some adjectives and adverbs.

Polarity.title: polarity
Polarity.description: Polarity is typically a feature of verbs, adjectives, sometimes also adverbs and nouns in languages that negate using bound morphemes.

Person.title: person
Person.description: Person is typically feature of personal and possessive pronouns / determiners, and of verbs. On verbs it is in fact an agreement feature that marks the person of the verb’s subject.

Polite.title: politeness
Polite.description: Various languages have various means to express politeness or respect; some of the means are morphological. Three to four dimensions of politeness are distinguished in linguistic literature.

Clusivity.title: clusivity
Clusivity.description: Clusivity is a feature of first-person plural personal pronouns. As such, it can also be reflected by inflection of verbs.
